This work reports crystalline MnO2 nanomaterials as a sustainable catalyst, for economical synthesis of N-substituted formamides and N-methyl amine products in the presence of air:O2 mixture (9:1) using bio-derived glycerol. This process provides flexible selectivity tuning between N-formamides and N-methyl amines, based on MnO2 crystal structure and glycerol concentration. The as-prepared (α, β, γ & δ) MnO2 nanostructures have been characterized in detail. This process was tested further with γ-MnO2 nanorods, which delivers yields in the range of 43-90% for a diverse substrate library of 16 amine substrates for N-formamide products and β-MnO2 for synthesis of N-methyl amines from secondary amines. The varied crystalline MnO2 nanostructures and their surface Mn (III)/Mn (IV) species ratios have been shown to steer the selectivity of the reaction differently, where α- and γ-MnO2 forming N-formamide with higher selectivity, while β- and δ-MnO2 leans more towards formation of N-methyl amine and N-formamide equally. The reusability of MnO2 catalysts up to 7 runs has been shown. The gram scale synthesis of formamides also shows yields of up to 75% using γ-MnO2 at pre-determined parameters. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Glycerol Manganese oxide N-Formamide Aerobic Oxidation N-methyl amine Data Availability The data has been made available in the supplementary material of the article. Introduction Efficient extraction and effective industrial application of biomass platform molecules are the pillars of formation of carbon neutral cycle partly, in theory [1]. There are a number of biorefinery platform molecules which have been shown to have great industrial scalability potential such as levulinic acid, sorbitol, succinic acid, xylitol and glycerol [2,3]. Interestingly, glycerol is one of the by-products from biodiesel production, while being an important biomass derived building block and inexpensive raw material in high industrial demand, with globally projected production to reach 4 million metric tons annually with global glycerol market reaching 3.5B US$ by 2027 [4]. The scientific community has been allocating resources for the challenge of exploring more pathways for utilizing this inexpensive industrial by-product for production of value-added chemicals [5,6]. There are many avenues that need to be explored in scenarios with glycerol being the reactant for synthesis of value-added chemicals. Recently, glycerol and other platform molecules have been converted into many valuable chemicals with numerous applications, by using processes such as hydrogenolysis, transesterification, etherification and fermentation processes [7–10]. Still, the applications of glycerol as a raw material in the field of fine chemical syntheses are seldom to be found. Transition metal oxides nanostructures, mainly first row transition metals have been of major importance in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, due to their economic value, easy availability and relatively robust performance in catalytic reactions [11,12]. Being one of these materials, Manganese dioxide (MnO2) is a versatile earth-abundant transition metal oxide with varied applications in the field of catalysis,[13] supercapacitors [14] especially due to its wide redox window on both ends. Over the last decade, great effort has been applied to tuning the size, crystal structure, oxidation states, surface area and morphologies of the MnO2 material to increase their catalytic activity and applicability to real world use [15]. Manganese oxides has been shown to be quite effective in oxidation reactions for different molecules such as oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural to produce FDCA [16], removal and degradation of gaseous pollutants [17] and artificial photosynthesis [18]. Primarily, the catalytic ability of the transition metal oxide depends on its crystal structure, which affects the utilization of its existing redox cycle and surface active sites, to translate to higher catalytic performance for any reaction [19]. Hence, based on this hypothesis, we aim to explore the catalytic activity of (α, β, γ & δ phases of MnO2 and commercial activated MnO2) manganese oxide nanostructures for applying glycerol as a building block for converting primary and secondary amines into different amine coupling products such as N-formamides and N-methyl amines, shown in Fig. 1 . The reports for this reaction process are limited using molecular oxygen, being only one, which includes using Cu sites in CuNiAlOx alloy catalyst for synthesis of N-formamide and N-methyl amines with physical parameters at 150°C and O2 pressure (5 bar) [20]. Herein, we show that different MnO2 crystalline nanostructures can act as a sustainable, inexpensive and efficient catalyst for synthesis of formamides with glycerol as a N-formylation source and N-methylation source for synthesis of N-methyl amines, using different amines. Experimental Manganous sulfate hydrate (MnSO4. H2O) (extrapure AR, 99 %) was requisitioned from Spectrochem, India and Potassium Permanganate (AR/ACS, 99.0 %) was purchased from Loba Chemie. Ammonium persulfate (reagent grade, 98 %) was acquired from Sigma Aldrich. Glucose (extrapure AR, ACS) was purchased from Spectrochem, India. Commercial activated MnO2 (activated, ∼85%, <10 μm) was obtained from Sigma Aldrich. All amine substrates in AR grade purity were purchased from brands such as Sigma Aldrich, Alfa Aesar and TCI. Glycerol (≥99.5%) was obtained from Sigma Aldrich, India, with a water content of ≤0.20% water (Karl Fischer). All the solvents (AR grade) were obtained from Alfa Aesar. All these chemicals obtained were used further without any prior purification. The different MnO2 nanostructures (α, β, γ, δ) were synthesized using different methods involving hydrothermal and xerogel methods with minor changes [21,22]. Synthesis of α-MnO2 : It was synthesized by hydrothermal method, where 0.50 g of KMnO4 and 0.21 g of MnSO4·H2O were dissolved separately in deionized water (15 mL each). Once dissolved, they were mixed together and magnetically stirred for 20 minutes. This mixture was later transferred to a Teflon lined hydrothermal reactor and heated to 160°C for 12 h. The catalyst was centrifuged and separated by decantation and oven dried at 80°C overnight. Synthesis of β-MnO2 : Identical procedure was followed for β-MnO2 synthesis distinguished only by differing quantities of MnSO4·H2O (0.45 g) and KMnO4 (0.28 g) used for the prior process. Synthesis of γ-MnO2 : It was synthesized using the hydrothermal method as well, which involved mixing of MnSO4·H2O solution (1.35 g in 20 mL deionized water) and (NH4)2S2O8 solution (1.83 g in 20 mL deionized water). The mixture was then transferred to Teflon lined hydrothermal reactor to be treated at 90°C for 24 h. Synthesis of δ-MnO2 : δ-MnO2 was synthesized using xerogel method where a 40 mL solution of KMnO4 (3.00 g) in deionized water was transferred dropwise to 1.4 M glucose solution in 20 mL deionized water over the period of 15 minutes. The solution was stirred vigorously for another 15 minutes. A thick brown gel formed which undergoes syneresis (expulsion of water from the gel). The supernatant was discarded slowly over a few hours. The as-prepared xerogel was oven dried at 110°C for 24 h. It was later calcined at 400°C for 2 h to yield a brown powder. General reaction procedure: The amine substrate reactions for N-formamide and N-methyl amine synthesis were conducted as per this procedure: 0.5 mmol of amine, 30 mg catalyst (γ- or β-MnO2 as per requirement), 0.3 mmol of glycerol (10 mmol glycerol for N-methyl amine reaction) and 5 mL dioxane were measured and transferred to a high-pressure autoclave. The autoclave was then put under 1 bar of oxygen pressure and later filled with 9 bar of air with a total pressure of 10 bar [WARNING: Please exercise caution while using pressurized oxygen at elevated temperatures]. The autoclave was allowed to heat to required temperature of 90°C and run for 12 h at 1000 rpm agitation speed. After 12 h, the autoclave was cooled and the catalyst was separated from reaction mixture by centrifugation. Identical procedure was followed all the substrates listed in Figs. 6 and 7 (a temperature of 100°C was applied for N-methyl amine synthesis substrates). For product purification using column chromatography, the solvent was removed using rotary evaporator. 15 mL dil. HCl solution was added to the residue and stirred. Later, this solution was washed with 4 × 5 mL of dichloromethane to separate the formamide product. This organic solution was separated and treated with Na2SO4 and further purified by column chromatography using PET ether/EtOAc system. The purified products were dried and weighed to determine the isolated yield of products. These products were then analyzed using 1H, 13C NMR and GC-MS analyses. Reusability tests procedure: The usual procedure followed by reusability tests is as follows: Similar procedure was followed for setting up the fresh run of the reaction as per the general reaction procedure section. After the fresh run was completed, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation of the reaction mixture. The recovered catalyst was washed with acetone three times. It was later dried at 70°C for 6 hours. The obtained material was again used for the next runs following the identical procedure mentioned above at the end of each run. Results and discussion Material characterization These synthesized nanostructures were further characterized using techniques such as Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), BET surface area analysis (BET), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). PXRD analysis assisted in confirming the crystal structures of the synthesized materials and matching them with their typical spectra available in the literature, presented in Fig. 2 . Formation of tetragonal α-MnO2 (Fig. 2a) was confirmed with its main characteristic peaks appearing at 12.5°, 28.9°, 37.5°, matching well with the JCPDS 00−044−0141. The other MnO2 nanostructures also matched well with their respective literature values namely β-MnO2 (JCPDS 00−024−0735) with tetragonal structure (Fig. 2b) with crystal planes (110), (101) and (211) appearing at 28.8°, 37.46° and 56.81°. γ-MnO2 (JCPDS 00−014−0644) of orthorhombic structure (Fig. 2c) exhibited distinguishing peaks at 22.61°, 37.07° and 56.13 .[23]. While, δ-MnO2 with trigonal structure (JCPDS 01−073−7867) (Fig. 2d) showed a fine particle size spectra with small intensity peaks at 11.9° and 36.17° [16]. Further, SEM analysis was utilized to deduce the morphology and the particle scale of these materials in Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3A, α-MnO2 nanoparticles shows a mixture of nanorod and nanoflake morphology with particles clumped together to form nanospheres. The particles size roughly lies in the range of 300-500 nm. SEM images for β-MnO2 (Fig. 3B) present nanorod morphology with their assembly to form nanospheres akin to materials like nano-fibrous silica. The particle size for these nanoparticles is around 200-400 nm. Moreover, γ-MnO2 (Fig. 3C) exhibited similar morphology to that of β-MnO2, with nanorods forming nanospheres with particle size in the range of 350-500 nm. However, δ-MnO2 (Fig. 3D) exhibited completely different morphology from the typical trend of the other MnO2 nanostructures, displaying fine particle size below 50 nm with no definite morphology. To determine the changes in surface area as per the different phases of MnO2, BET surface analysis technique was employed to all the nanostructures. As in Table 1 the changes in BET surface area are fairly minimal with the only exception being δ-MnO2, with the relatively high surface area of 95.6 m2/g. It is a fair observation as it matches well with the SEM data, where the significant particle size difference can be observed between the δ-MnO2 and other MnO2 nanostructures. The same trend for the average pore diameter being the smallest at 58.9 Å for δ-MnO2, compared to other MnO2 materials. γ-MnO2 does exhibit slightly higher surface area than β-MnO2 at 87.1 m2/g, which may be due to smaller size of nanorods, supported by SEM imaging. The other materials have nearly the same surface area, pore sizes and even pore volume, which may aid as a point of reference, while comparing the catalytic performance of these nanostructures. We have also added the physisorption isotherms for all MnO2 nanostructures in Fig. S4 of the ESI. Now, we will discuss the overall catalytic effect of all these properties on the selectivity and conversion of the reaction discussed earlier. Activity studies Glycerol has been generally found to have limited applications as a reducing agent, solvent, reagent and a reactant. In our process, glycerol acts as a building block offering up formyl as wells as methyl functionalities to the N site of primary or secondary amines. Recently, our group has also reported application of bio-derived feedstocks for N-formamide synthesis using TBHP in catalyst free condition with excellent results. [33]. For this process, we have also used a mixture of air:O2 pressure for these reactions in a ratio of 9:1. This step aids the reaction to be less hazardous at elevated temperatures by using smaller quantity of oxygen at high pressures while the excess nitrogen present in the air acts a safety buffer. The reactions were also conducted under 10 bar of air atmosphere as well to see if oxygen use can be replaced (Control experiments pg. 7 ESI). However, the % conversions for each of the 3 reaction runs carried out in 10 bar air pressure were not consistent probably due to uneven amounts of oxygen available to the catalyst surface for each separate run. Thus, to alleviate the issue of reproducibility with using air pressure, 1 bar of oxygen was mixed with 9 bars of air to keep oxygen quantity in excess to drive the reaction, which have been noted in the control experiments section in the ESI. The synthesized MnO2 nanostructures and even commercial activated MnO2 oxidize glycerol via radical based mechanism to generate activated radicals, which are spontaneously trapped by the amine to generate the corresponding N-formyl amine counterpart. The same case follows for formation of N-methyl amine with trapping of radical generated from the treatment of glycerol with MnO2. Additionally, the amine substrate contributes by initiating the reaction, acting as a base as well as the reactant. In absence of amine, MnO2 cannot react with glycerol at all. To prove this, we conducted a reaction of glycerol using MnO2 at similar conditions in absence of amine substrate or any other base additive and tested the reaction mixture using HPLC analysis, which showed no conversion of glycerol (Control Experiments pg.7 ESI). The next step was selecting the solvent for the reaction as it plays a major role in this reaction added in the ESI (Table S2). Aniline was chosen as the substrate to gauge the solvents as it is a primary amine which may form multiple side products. But to our surprise, the results presented quantitative selectivity, however, changes in % conversion were observed for different solvents. The polar protic solvents such as ethanol, water showed % conversion around 50% to N-formamide product (Table S3 Entry 1 and 2). Polar aprotic solvents such as acetonitrile, dioxane, THF presented different % conversions to N-formamide altogether with dioxane showing 81% conversion to N-formamide product (Table S3 Entry 2), while THF and acetonitrile exhibiting much lower conversion of 59% and 68% respectively (Table S3 Entry 5 and 7). Non-polar solvents such as toluene and bio-derived solvent 2-methyl THF exhibited the lowest conversion of 7% and 11% respectively (Table S3 Entry 4 and 6). Based on these results, dioxane was chosen to be the solvent for this reaction to carry out reaction parameters testing using morpholine substrate, which is necessary to determine how the parameters affect the selectivity of N-formamides and N-methyl amine products, in case of secondary amines (Table 2 ). The parameters that were studied were temperature, glycerol concentration, amount of catalyst and duration. At non-optimal conditions, the highest conversion of morpholine was showed by γ-MnO2 at 97% with a selectivity of 86% for the N-formyl product and 14% for the N-methyl product (Table 2 Entry 4). It piqued our interest that, different selectivity for these two products were observed based on the different MnO2 crystal structures. While α- (Table 2 Entry 2) and γ-MnO2 (Table 2 Entry 4) showed higher selectivity towards N-formamide product, β- (Table 2 Entry 3) and δ-MnO2 (Table 2 Entry 5) leaned more towards formation of N-methyl amine and N-formamide product in almost equal ratios. Activated MnO2 (Table 2 Entry 6 and 7) also exhibited 52% and 72% conversion and selectivity at catalyst amount of 50 mg and 100 mg respectively, with higher selectivity for N-formamide product. Then, we tested the temperature effect in the range of 80-120°C using γ-MnO2 as it provides highest conversions for this process. At 100°C, the selectivity and conversion did not exhibit any major differences than the previous run at 120°C. The next run at 80°C showed selectivity for N-formylation product at 96% with lower conversion of 70% (Table 2 Entry 10). While at 60°C, the conversion drastically dropped to 23% (Table 2 Entry 11) with only the N-formyl product being formed. Hence, further reactions were carried out at 90°C for the remainder of the study. Further, effects of glycerol concentration on conversion and selectivity were conducted, which showed that the selectivity of N-methyl amine product increasing steadily as we increased the glycerol concentration up to 10 mmol. The increased glycerol concentration of 10 mmol (Table 2 Entry 16) provides a comparable selectivity of 43% using γ-MnO2 to the 48% achieved by β-MnO2 in catalyst screening. Hence, these same reaction conditions were applied using β-MnO2 to observe if the selectivity can be improved for the N-methyl amine product. However, only limited increase to 59% was detected for selectivity of N-methyl amine with slight increase in % conversion of amine (Table 2 Entry 17). Later, we determined the optimal amount of the catalyst amount down to 30 mg with similar conversions (Table 2 Entry 19). The best reaction duration with maximum conversion was found for this reaction, where it was found that 12 h resulted in balance between high conversion and selectivity of N-formamide product (Table 2 Entry 24). The reaction conversion dropped at 10 h to 79% with selectivity achieved for N-formamide product as expected. To explain the selectivity results for this reaction using these nanostructures, we conducted additional characterizations to help understand the differences of these MnO2 nanostructures. We conducted HR-TEM analysis for β-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 to better understand any morphology or particle size differences in these two materials. HR-TEM imaging and SAED patterns analysis also aided to correlate the data of these MnO2 nanostructures with the PXRD analysis. Fig. 4 A and C show the HR-TEM images for β-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 respectively. β-MnO2 nanorods have much larger width and length compared to γ-MnO2 (30-70 nm width and 300-500 nm length), with 100-150 nm in width and lengths more than 1 μm. The subset in Fig. 4A, shows the fringe width (d) at 0.32 nm, which corresponds to the (110) crystal plane, which matches well with the PXRD analysis of β-MnO2. Similarly, the subset in Fig. 4C, highlights the fringe spacing of 0.384 nm, which corresponds to the (110) plane of γ-MnO2. The SAED pattern analysis for both nanostructures agree well with PXRD data, with major crystal planes highlighted in Fig. 4B and D. To determine the surface activity of these catalysts, we analyzed these materials using XPS technique, which helps explaining these changes in selectivity by changes in the crystal structure of the catalyst. Fig. 5 and Table 3 show the Mn 2p region and the deconvoluted peak compositions for Mn (II), Mn (III) and Mn (IV) at 640.8 eV, 641.8 eV and 642.8 eV respectively for all 4 MnO2 nanostructures [24]. From this data, we were able to observe a trend which might explain the catalytic behavior of these catalysts. It appears that these materials act as an oxidation catalyst in this reaction, based on the redox cycle of Mn (III)/Mn (IV) and follows the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism for oxidation of glycerol in two steps a) Oxidation of substrate at MnO2 surface to form partially reduced MnOx species and b) Re-oxidation of the surface MnOx species using molecular oxygen [25]. The changes to the concentration of the Mn (III)/Mn (IV) species on the catalyst surface seems to be causing an effect in terms of differing selectivity of N-formamide and N-methyl amine products. It can be observed in Table 3, that α-MnO2 (61.1%) and γ-MnO2 (53.3%) have relatively high concentration of Mn (IV) species presence on the surface. While β-MnO2 and δ-MnO2 had fairly balanced concentrations of Mn (III) and Mn (IV) presence. This might the cause of 50/50 distribution of selectivity for N-formamide and N-methyl amine been observed in case of β-MnO2 and δ-MnO2. One of the other observations made from this data is that γ-MnO2 had the lowest concentration of Mn (II) species on the surface compared to all the other nanostructures. This points to another trend of % conversion from Table 2, where higher Mn (II) species leads to lower conversions with only exception being δ-MnO2 with higher conversion despite having the highest Mn (II) species concentration from all 4 materials. However, other factors such as much smaller particle size, relatively larger surface area might be contributing to its higher % conversion for δ-MnO2. The XPS survey data (Fig. S1) and the O 1s regions (Fig. S2) for all MnO2 nanostructures have been added to the ESI for reference. The next step was to apply these pre-determined reaction conditions to a wide substrate library of amines and observe the selected MnO2 nanostructures catalytic performance. Based on the process parameter study results, γ-MnO2 was chosen for synthesis of formamide library due to its highest conversion and formamide selectivity results (Fig. 6 ). Firstly, aliphatic cyclic secondary amines such as morpholine (1a), piperidine (1b), indoline (1c) exhibited 82%, 90%, 89% yields respectively for the corresponding formamide product. Then, acyclic aliphatic secondary amines were tested such as di-n-butylamine (1d) and diethylamine (1e), which also provided 75% and 81% yields respectively. We then moved on to secondary aniline and benzylamine substrates, which afforded yields in the range of 72-81% (1f-1h) with only exception being the N-tert-butyl benzylamine substrate (1i) with a 49% yield by low conversion possibly due to steric factor of tert-butyl group in the immediate vicinity. Primary amines were the ones that were explored in the next step, starting with cyclohexylamine (1j) which gave a yield of 85% for formamide product. Then, different substituted anilines were used to show the variations in yields based on steric and electronic effects associated with different functional groups present on the aromatic ring. Aniline (1k) provided a yield of 73%, while the activating substitutions such as methoxy groups increased the yield for this reaction to 79% and 82% for meta-substituted (1l) and di-substituted aniline (1m) respectively. Difluoro methoxy substituted aniline substrate (1n) with deactivating effect still showed a yield of 64%. Steric effect on yields of aniline products was explored by using 2,4,6-trimethyl aniline (1o) and 2,6-diethyl aniline (1p), where the yields did drop to 56% and 43% respectively. We then explored other reactants for N-formylation such as o-phenylenediamine (1q), where we made an interesting observation. When the MnO2 catalyst was added to the o-phenylenediamine (1q) solution, the catalyst would dissolve almost instantaneously, with solution turning dark red-orange color. This phenomenon was observed due to the chelating effect of o-phenylenediamine substrate, siphoning Mn ions from the catalyst surface forming Mn (III) or Mn (IV) complexes [26]. o-amino benzonitrile (1r), showed no conversion, due to the severely low Pka (∼0.77) of o-amino benzonitrile, which fails to activate the oxidation of glycerol to form formyl radicals [27]. We also carried out scaled-up reaction using morpholine, which provided yields up to 75% for N-formyl morpholine with 89% conversion. We additionally explored N-methyl amine synthesis using β-MnO2 as a catalyst at higher glycerol concentration (10 mmol) and 10°C bump in temperature (Fig. 7 ). However, this reaction shows a limited substrate scope with secondary amines providing N-methyl amine products with moderate yields using this protocol. As expected, morpholine (2a) and piperidine (2b) showed yields up to 56% and 58% of methyl amine product respectively. While benzylamine substrate yields got lowered due to formation of formamide in higher quantity and mainly one side product such as benzaldehyde. Still, N-methylbenzylamine (2c) and Dibenzylamine (2d) produced moderate yields of 24% and 30% respectively. We also tested N-methyl aniline substrate (2e), which exhibited a yield of 41%, higher as compared to benzylamine substrates. Primary amine showed no presence of N-methyl amine product under these conditions. The reusability of these nanostructures was the next step in determining the robustness of these materials as a catalyst for this reaction. We conducted both reactions for synthesis of N-formamide product and N-methyl amine product using γ-MnO2 and β-MnO2 respectively for 7 runs to observe changes to yields and catalysts surface. Reactions for N-formamide synthesis showed a steady decline, with the yields dropping from 85% to 59% in the 7 runs (Fig. 10). There was a similar trend observed for N-methyl amine yields where the yields fell from 56% to just 21% (Fig. 11). The overall drop in yields for both the cases was observed due to dips in % conversion of amines, while almost similar selectivity of products was observed for all runs. The drop in % conversion in case of β-MnO2 was much more pronounced than γ-MnO2. To determine the extent of Mn leaching in both the catalysts, we conducted ICP-OES analysis for both the fresh run reaction solutions using these catalysts. It was found that γ-MnO2 reaction solution showed negligible leaching at Mn concentration of 0.9 ppm, while β-MnO2 reaction solution gave a Mn concentration of 3.8 ppm. The higher Mn leaching content in case of β-MnO2 might be due to the high glycerol concentration driving conversion of Mn (III) or Mn (IV) surface species to Mn (II) resulting in relatively greater Mn leaching. In the next stage, we then characterized the recovered recycle catalyst using XPS technique, which helps in determining the descending catalytic activity of the catalyst for this reaction. In Fig. 8 and Table 4 , fresh and 7th run recycle β-MnO2 catalyst have been compared, where it clearly shows the surge in Mn (II) species concentration from 5.1% to 47.1%, while Mn (IV) species concentration getting reduced to 11.3% with prior being 37.3%. As for γ-MnO2, the data in Fig. 9 and Table 5 exhibits similar tendencies, however, the drop in catalytic performance is not as severe as compared to β-MnO2. Mn (III) concentration observed almost no changes over the course of the 7 runs of the reaction for both MnO2 catalysts. The XPS data for γ-MnO2 also presented a sharp dip in Mn (IV) concentration from 53.3% to 27.3% and a surge in Mn (II) species from 3.2% to 27.6%. This does help show that Mn (II) species on the catalyst surface caused the drops in yields of the reaction. There have been other studies showing the manganese oxide catalytic activity considerably dropping with presence of lower oxidation states Mn species in the catalyst [24,28]. The catalytic activity of these nanostructures can be regained up to a certain extent by reoxidation of reused catalyst in oxygen, however, complete oxidation to MnO2 is only possible at extremely high oxygen pressure and high temperature [29]. We have also added recycle catalyst XPS survey spectra and the elemental quantification of all MnO2 nanostructures in the Fig. S3 and Table S1 of the ESI. Fig. 12 shows the proposed mechanism for this reaction based on XPS analysis and process parameter results for this reaction. The figure has been divided into four quadrants for better understanding of the involved steps. The first step involves the activation of oxidation of glycerol on MnO2 surface at the Mn (IV) site by morpholine acting as a base. The Mn (IV) site gets reduced to Mn (III), while glycerol forms dihydroxyacetone [30,31]. Dihydroxyacetone further breaks homolytically at the carbonyl site to form radicals, which are trapped by morpholine to form activated species [32]. The surface Mn (III) sites gets re-oxidized to Mn (IV) using molecular oxygen, however, the rate of reoxidation appears to be much lower evidently by the XPS analysis of the recycled catalyst. Based on XPS data, higher Mn (IV) species on the surface leads to higher selectivity for N-formamide product, so it can be shown in the third quadrant that the activated species gets converted to formamide with formation of water as a side product. While balanced Mn (III)/ Mn (IV) species on the catalyst surface leads to almost 50/50 selectivity of N-formamide and N-methyl amine product. In the fourth quadrant, Mn (III) site reduces the activated species with excess glycerol as H atom donor by transfer hydrogenation. This can be supported by the fact that we observed greater selectivity for N-methyl amine while using higher concentrations of glycerol in the reaction. While reduction of Mn (IV) to Mn (II) species at the surface causes drops in % conversion of amines, as it disturbs the redox cycle necessary for this conversion [28]. This was also agreeing well with the earlier data on % conversion data in Table 2 for each MnO2 nanostructure except δ-MnO2, where Mn (II) species concentration controlled the % conversion with γ-MnO2 having the highest conversion numbers with the lowest percentage of Mn (II) species (∼3%) at the surface. Conclusion Different crystalline MnO2 nanostructures showed intriguing results for this reaction based on their surface environment. The selectivity tuning for formation of desired product was mainly shown to depend on two conditions, which were MnO2 crystal structure used and the other being the glycerol concentration applied to the reaction. XPS data agreed well with this observation with the selectivity depending on the balance of the Mn (III)/ Mn (IV) redox cycle. α- and γ-MnO2 were able to show greater selectivity for N-formamide product based on the higher Mn (IV) species percentage on the surface, whereas, β- and δ-MnO2 exhibited a 50/50 % selectivity scenario for N-formamide and N-methyl amine product, based on the balance of Mn (III)/ Mn (IV) species on their surface. The reusability data was also able to help understand the drops in yields and conversion, due to the redox imbalance created by increase in Mn (II) species on the MnO2 surface. γ-MnO2 was found to be an efficient catalyst for conversion of wide and varied library of primary and secondary amines to corresponding formamides. β-MnO2 as a catalyst was relatively more inclined towards formation of both amine coupling products in equal ratios, however, the substrate scope for this conversion was narrower being limited to secondary amines. This reaction is an industrially relevant process, which should be studied further in terms of selectivity tuning of products based on the type of catalytic system applied and the reaction parameters. coredata.dc:description: This work reports crystalline MnO2 nanomaterials as a sustainable catalyst, for economical synthesis of N-substituted formamides and N-methyl amine products in the presence of air:O2 mixture (9:1) using bio-derived glycerol. This process provides flexible selectivity tuning between N-formamides and N-methyl amines, based on MnO2 crystal structure and glycerol concentration. The as-prepared (α, β, γ & δ) MnO2 nanostructures have been characterized in detail. This process was tested further with γ-MnO2 nanorods, which delivers yields in the range of 43-90% for a diverse substrate library of 16 amine substrates for N-formamide products and β-MnO2 for synthesis of N-methyl amines from secondary amines. The varied crystalline MnO2 nanostructures and their surface Mn (III)/Mn (IV) species ratios have been shown to steer the selectivity of the reaction differently, where α- and γ-MnO2 forming N-formamide with higher selectivity, while β- and δ-MnO2 leans more towards formation of N-methyl amine and N-formamide equally. The reusability of MnO2 catalysts up to 7 runs has been shown. The gram scale synthesis of formamides also shows yields of up to 75% using γ-MnO2 at pre-determined parameters.
coredata.dc:title: MnO2 nanostructures as sustainable catalysts for selectivity tuning and syntheses of amine coupling products with bio-derived glycerol
